content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Locate a Coursera Guided project related to 'Astrophysics' suitable for advanced learners. Mention the course duration, the institution offering it, and the main subjects covered in the course.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find a Coursera Guided project related to 'Astrophysics', I need to use the search function. The search button is labeled [2]. Clicking this will likely open a textbox where I can enter the keyword "Astrophysics".
Action: Click [2]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is now visible at [1] and ready for input. I should type "Astrophysics" to find relevant guided projects.
Action: Type [1]; Astrophysics
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search has returned some physics-related specializations and courses, but none of the visible results mention "Astrophysics" or are marked as "Guided Project." I need to scroll down to see if relevant guided projects about astrophysics and for advanced learners are available further below.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The currently visible results are still not related to Astrophysics and none are marked as Coursera Guided Projects. I need to continue scrolling down to see more relevant results.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible results are still not related to Astrophysics or Guided Projects. I need to scroll further down to locate a course specifically about Astrophysics and with the Guided Project label for advanced learners.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The courses shown cover general and introductory physics topics, not astrophysics and none are labeled as Guided Projects. To increase chances of finding "Astrophysics" and filter by Guided Project, I can look for more subject filters by clicking “Show 4 more” [10] under “Subject,” as filtering by subject might narrow to astrophysics or space science.
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Additional subject filters are now visible, but none obviously pertain to Astrophysics or Space Science. The filter options might not be sufficient. I need to continue scrolling to look for a "Guided Project" filter, which will help to specifically look for Guided Projects in the search results.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: A new course called "Voyages de l'infiniment grand à l'infiniment petit" offered by École Polytechnique is visible, which translates to "Journeys from the infinitely large to the infinitely small." This may relate to astrophysics, but it is listed as a "Specialization," not a "Guided Project." There are still no Guided Project options visible. I need to continue scrolling to search for courses or apply a filter for Guided Projects if available.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The course "Astronomía básica" (Basic Astronomy) by Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, and another course from the University of Arizona titled "Astrophysics: Exploring Time and Space," are visible. The latter likely matches the query's field, but it is not labeled as a "Guided Project." I do not yet see any Guided Project tag for astrophysics; I should scroll further to look for courses specifically tagged as Guided Projects.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is a course titled "Astronomy: Exploring Time and Space" by the University of Arizona and "Advanced Spacecraft Dynamics and Control" by the University of Colorado Boulder. The latter is marked as a "Specialization" and has "Advanced" in the title, which may be suitable for advanced learners. None of these are labeled as "Guided Project." I still need to scroll further to search for any "Guided Project" in astrophysics.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current results include specializations and courses related to science and space (such as "New Space: Access to space - Basics"), but still, none are labeled as a Guided Project or are directly advanced astrophysics-focused. I should continue scrolling further to try to find a Guided Project in the astrophysics domain, as the visible options do not fit the specific requirements.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The results shown are still not labeled as Guided Projects, and none specifically mention Astrophysics—though there are courses about quantum physics and data visualization. I still have not seen a Guided Project matching the criteria. I should keep scrolling to exhaust the visible options, as there may still be additional results further down.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.55

content:

However, it is categorized as a "Course" and not as a "Guided Project." The lower portion of the screen shows more options, but none are marked "Guided Project." I should scroll further to try to locate any "Guided Project" related to astrophysics.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.6
